Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor John Gladysz of the Department of Chemistry at Texas A&M University will explore both the synthesis and detailed chemical and physical characterization of two types of organometallic molecular devices, wire-like and gyroscope-like complexes. The former features sp-hybridized carbon chains that span transition metal fragments. The gyroscopes feature MLn fragments encaged by two trans-phosphorus atoms that are tethered by three hydrocarbon chains. The macrocyclic dibridgehead diphosphines can be decomplexed under certain conditions, undergo a fascinating dynamic process by which they turn themselves inside-out, and synergistically constitute promising ligands for some of the wire-like compounds.

The miniaturization of macroscopic devices represents one of the greatest challenges as society continually strives for smaller and more powerful and efficient consumer products such as mobile phones, computers, and personal and commercial vehicles. Molecular wires are necessary for the realization of molecular circuits and electronics. This project will provide broad in-depth professional training for undergraduate and graduate student coworkers, as well as postdoctorals. They will acquire cutting edge laboratory skills and develop their writing and oral presentation capabilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The findings derived from this project have a profound impact upon fundamental chemistry and point the way to diverse types of practical applications. Everyone is familiar with the technologically important all-carbon polymers graphite and diamond, which are derived from sp2 and sp3 hybridized networks, respectively. However, few are aware that a third polymeric allotrope is possible, "carbyne", derived from a sp hybridized network. This study has made the synthesis and characterization of models for carbyne possible, and helped to define exploitable properties.

Another thrust has involved the miniaturization of machines and devices to the smallest possible (namely molecular) level. Thus, new methodologies have been developed for the construction of (1) (insulated) molecular wires based upon carbyne fragments and (2) molecular gyroscopes that structurally resemble classical toy gyroscopes. In appropriate cases, the gyroscope cages can be detached from the rotating components, giving rare examples of molecules that can "turn themselves inside out". In one form, key atoms (usually phosphorus) direct their binding sites inwards, and in the other form key atoms direct their binding sites outwards, towards the environment. This "inside out" property allows the phosphorus containing species to serve as "container molecules" and transport precious metals away from base metals (for example, platinum and palladium away from nickel). This is conceptually similar to harvesting gold from sea water, an objective for the next phase of this work.

This "inside out" phenomena has been further exploited to engineer molecules with totally new types of connectivities or topologies, related to the types of knots and similar structures that are well known from the basic training exercises of Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts.

The research involving carbyne has a direct impact upon polymer science, providing new materials with new properties, quite analogous to that of graphene. The molecular wires and molecular gyroscopes have a direct impact upon nanotechnology. In particular, gyroscopes are ubiquitous in modern technology, and all of the physics holds at the molecular level. To name just two examples, the i-Phone and many other mobile phones have gyroscopes that maintain the proper orientation of the graphics on the screens, and all drones use gyroscopes for orientation and navigation. For obvious reasons, there is ongoing pressure for increasing miniaturization, for which the ultimate would be a molecular level device.

The research activities have provided training and educational development for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral associates and high school teachers, not only as researchers but as teachers and leaders. These have included a significant numbers of women and underrepresented groups who have garnered many awards and fellowships. The broad technical, intellectual, and presentation skills acquired via this project provide a very strong foundation for future careers in a number of fields. In depth safety training has also been an intrinsic part of this project.

The PI and all coworkers have participated in outreach activities, such as the annual chemistry department open house, where they carry out a variety of demonstrations involving gyroscopes. In December of 2016 the PI was one of six featured speakers at the "Texas A&M Nobel Prizes Symposium", which was targeted at and open to the Bryan/College Station lay community. His task was to distill the essence of the 2016 chemistry Nobel Prize into a 15 minute presentation. Since the Prize was awarded for molecular machines some of the gyroscope chemistry was presented. This lecture (as well as other activities associated with this project) has been abstracted in social media and posted to You-Tube:

 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g7Fy5rGUM1o

http://www.science.tamu.edu/news/story.php?story_ID=1706 - .WF2joneZMxM

All aspects of the data generated by this project (collection, storage, protection, retention, analysis, sharing, reporting) have been administered according to a rigorous "data management plan". All five doctoral dissertations completed within the framework of this project have been placed online by Texas A&M University and are available free of charge to the public.

Gyroscopes are essential components of a variety of consumer products, many of which are considered "empowering" from the standpoint of enabling new ways of acquiring knowledge, facilitating new types of social interactions, and allowing access of lay personnel to formerly closed or difficultly entered fields. Thus, there is the potential for transformative impact upon the way individuals lead their lives. Also, gyroscopes would certainly play a key role in (for example) the colonization of Mars.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/22/2017
Modified by: John A Gladysz

  • Container Molecules Developed in this Project. They can selectively remove platinum and palladium from a solution that also contains the base metal nickel (as the chloride complexes)

    Copyrighted
    John A Gladysz
    Container Molecules Developed in this Project
